title: 103_hr82
content: Restoration of deduction for interest on educational loans. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for the deduction of interest on qualified educational loans. This includes loans provided through certain programs or by tax-exempt organizations. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code allows for the deduction of interest on qualified educational loans, including loans provided by tax-exempt organizations or financial institutions under specific programs. The deduction applies to interest incurred to pay for qualified educational expenses within a reasonable timeframe. The deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is subject to reduction based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. Specific dollar amounts and phaseout ranges apply depending on the filing status of the individual. The deduction for interest on qualified educational loans is subject to reduction based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income. The applicable dollar amount may be reduced to zero in certain cases. The deduction is allowable only for the first 48 months of repayment. Qualified educational expenses include tuition and related expenses for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependent attending an eligible educational institution. The term 'qualified tuition and related expenses' includes reasonable living expenses while away from home. The $40,000 and $60,000 amounts for phaseout are adjusted for inflation annually. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1993, for loans with the first required payment after that date. Amounts adjusted under the new rules are rounded to the nearest multiple of $50.
